importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year 2015 marks the start of the Paris Climate Agreement, which shifted global climate trajectories and reduced projected warming from 4C to 2.6C.
The study notes that since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days, indicating ongoing climate impacts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects that by 2100, the world will experience 57 additional superhot days annually, representing a significant and sustained climate risk.

keyTakeAways: Climate change is increasing the number of dangerous 'superhot days'—defined as warmer than 90% of comparable days from 1991–2020—by 57 per year under current emissions pathways.
The 2015 Paris Climate Agreement reduced projected warming from 4C to 2.6C, cutting the number of additional superhot days from 114 to 57.
Since 2015, the planet has already added 11 average superhot days.

The increase in extreme heat is highly unequal: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face vastly more superhot days than major emitters like the U.S., China, and India.
Panama is projected to face 149 additional superhot days annually, while top carbon-polluting countries face only 23–30 extra days despite being responsible for 42% of global CO₂ emissions.
The disparity illustrates a global injustice in climate impacts, with low-emitting, vulnerable nations bearing disproportionate heat exposure.
Experts warn that this climate heat inequality could deepen geopolitical tensions and widen the divide between rich and poor nations.

namedEntities.name: World Weather Attribution
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research organization that conducts climate attribution studies to assess the role of climate change in extreme weather events.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This organization led the study that calculated the increase in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific attribution to climate impacts.

namedEntities.name: Climate Central
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S.-based climate science organization that supports research on climate change impacts and data analysis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Climate Central collaborated with World Weather Attribution in the study, contributing expertise and infrastructure to analyze climate trends.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming to well below 2C, aiming for 1.5C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement changed global warming trajectories from 4C to 2.6C, directly influencing the projected number of superhot days from 114 to 57.

namedEntities.name: Potsdam Climate Institute
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research institute that conducts climate science and policy analysis, led by director Johan Rockstrom.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Johan Rockstrom, not part of the research team, provided expert commentary on the implications of the study's findings for global human safety.

namedEntities.name: Johan Rockstrom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of the Potsdam Climate Institute, an expert in climate science and policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He emphasized that even under current commitments, the world still faces a disastrous future due to climate impacts.

namedEntities.name: Friederike Otto
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Coauthor of the study and climate scientist at Imperial College London.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She highlighted that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by the additional superhot days, and that thousands die annually in heatwaves.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Weaver
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: University of Victoria climate scientist not involved in the research team.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He described the heat inequality as a driver of geopolitical instability and a growing divide between rich and poor nations.

namedEntities.name: Panama
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small, ocean-dependent nation in Central America.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Panama is projected to experience 149 additional superhot days annually, one of the highest increases among any country.

namedEntities.name: Solomon Islands
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small island nation in the South Pacific, highly vulnerable to climate change.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is among the 10 countries expected to face the largest increases in dangerous heat days, despite minimal emissions.

namedEntities.name: Samoa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small island nation in the South Pacific, highly exposed to climate impacts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Samoa is listed among the 10 countries with the largest projected increase in superhot days.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the world's largest carbon emitters.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Despite being responsible for a large share of global emissions, the U.S. is expected to face only 23–30 extra superhot days.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the world's largest carbon emitters and industrial powers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is projected to face only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite contributing 42% of global CO₂ emissions.

namedEntities.name: India
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major emitter and rapidly growing economy with significant energy demand.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: India is expected to face only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite its large emissions footprint.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current global climate commitments, the Earth will see 57 additional superhot days per year by 2100—nearly two months of dangerous heat—due to climate change. This represents a significant reduction from a pre-Paris scenario of 114 extra superhot days, thanks to the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement. However, the study reveals a stark global imbalance: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face disproportionately high heat exposure, with Panama expected to gain 149 extra superhot days annually. In contrast, the world’s largest emitters—U.S., China, and India—face only 23–30 extra days despite emitting 42% of global carbon dioxide. Experts warn that such disparities may deepen global injustice and trigger geopolitical instability, emphasizing that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by these extreme heat events.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
